segment.source: Launch the default app for a URI
segment.target: Launch the default app for a URI

segment.source: Learn how to launch the default app for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI).
segment.target: Learn how to launch the default app for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI).

segment.source: URIs allow you to launch another app to perform a specific task.
segment.target: URIs allow you to launch another app to perform a specific task.

segment.source: This topic also provides an overview of the many URI schemes built into Windows.
segment.target: This topic also provides an overview of the many URI schemes built into Windows.

segment.source: Launch the default app for a URI
segment.target: Launch the default app for a URI

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: LaunchUriAsync
segment.target: LaunchUriAsync

segment.source: PreferredApplicationPackageFamilyName
segment.target: PreferredApplicationPackageFamilyName

segment.source: DesiredRemainingView
segment.target: DesiredRemainingView

segment.source: Learn how to launch the default app for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI).
segment.target: Learn how to launch the default app for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI).

segment.source: URIs allow you to launch another app to perform a specific task.
segment.target: URIs allow you to launch another app to perform a specific task.

segment.source: This topic also provides an overview of the many URI schemes built into Windows.
segment.target: This topic also provides an overview of the many URI schemes built into Windows.

segment.source: You can launch custom URIs too.
segment.target: You can launch custom URIs too.

segment.source: For more info about registering a custom URI scheme and handling URI activation, see Handle URI activation.
segment.target: For more info about registering a custom URI scheme and handling URI activation, see Handle URI activation.

segment.source: How to launch a URI
segment.target: How to launch a URI

segment.source: URI schemes let you open apps by clicking hyperlinks.
segment.target: URI schemes let you open apps by clicking hyperlinks.

segment.source: Just as you can start a new email using mailto:, you can open the default web browser using http:.
segment.target: Just as you can start a new email using mailto:, you can open the default web browser using http:.

segment.source: This topic describes some of the URI schemes built into Windows:
segment.target: This topic describes some of the URI schemes built into Windows:

segment.source: The ms-settings: URI scheme launches the Windows Settings app
segment.target: The ms-settings: URI scheme launches the Windows Settings app

segment.source: The ms-store: URI scheme launches the Windows Store app
segment.target: The ms-store: URI scheme launches the Windows Store app

segment.source: The http: URI scheme launches the default web browser
segment.target: The http: URI scheme launches the default web browser

segment.source: The mailto: URI scheme launches the default email app
segment.target: The mailto: URI scheme launches the default email app

segment.source: The bingmaps:, ms-drive-to:, and ms-walk-to: URI schemes launch the Windows Maps app
segment.target: The bingmaps:, ms-drive-to:, and ms-walk-to: URI schemes launch the Windows Maps app

segment.source: For example, the following URI opens the default browser and displays the Bing web site.
segment.target: For example, the following URI opens the default browser and displays the Bing web site.

segment.source: You can also launch custom URI schemes too.
segment.target: You can also launch custom URI schemes too.

segment.source: If there is no app installed to handle that URI, you can recommend an app ror the user to install.
segment.target: If there is no app installed to handle that URI, you can recommend an app ror the user to install.

segment.source: For more info, see Recommend an app.
segment.target: For more info, see Recommend an app.

segment.source: In general, your app can't select the app that is launched.
segment.target: In general, your app can't select the app that is launched.

segment.source: The user determines which app is launched.
segment.target: The user determines which app is launched.

segment.source: More than one app can register to handle the same URI scheme.
segment.target: More than one app can register to handle the same URI scheme.

segment.source: The exception to this is for reserved URI schemes.
segment.target: The exception to this is for reserved URI schemes.

segment.source: Registrations of reserved URI schemes are ignored.
segment.target: Registrations of reserved URI schemes are ignored.

segment.source: For the full list of reserved URI schemes, see Handle URI activation.
segment.target: For the full list of reserved URI schemes, see Handle URI activation.

segment.source: In cases where more than one app may have registered the same URI scheme, your app can recommend a specific app to be launched.
segment.target: In cases where more than one app may have registered the same URI scheme, your app can recommend a specific app to be launched.

segment.source: For more info, see Recommend an app.
segment.target: For more info, see Recommend an app.

segment.source: Call LaunchUriAsync
segment.target: Call LaunchUriAsync

segment.source: Use the LaunchUriAsync method to launch a URI.
segment.target: Use the LaunchUriAsync method to launch a URI.

segment.source: When you call this method, your app must be the foreground app, that is, it must be visible to the user.
segment.target: When you call this method, your app must be the foreground app, that is, it must be visible to the user.

segment.source: This requirement helps ensure that the user remains in control.
segment.target: This requirement helps ensure that the user remains in control.

segment.source: To meet this requirement, make sure that you tie all URI launches directly to the UI of your app.
segment.target: To meet this requirement, make sure that you tie all URI launches directly to the UI of your app.

segment.source: The user must always take some action to initiate a URI launch.
segment.target: The user must always take some action to initiate a URI launch.

segment.source: If you attempt to launch a URI and your app isn't in the foreground, the launch will fail and your error callback will be invoked.
segment.target: If you attempt to launch a URI and your app isn't in the foreground, the launch will fail and your error callback will be invoked.

segment.source: First create a System.Uri object to represent the URI, then pass that to the LaunchUriAsync method.
segment.target: First create a System.Uri object to represent the URI, then pass that to the LaunchUriAsync method.

segment.source: Use the return result to see if the call succeeded, as shown in the following example.
segment.target: Use the return result to see if the call succeeded, as shown in the following example.

segment.source: In some cases, the operating system will prompt the user to see if the actually want to switch apps.
segment.target: In some cases, the operating system will prompt the user to see if the actually want to switch apps.

segment.source: a warning dialog overlayed on a grayed out background of the app.
segment.target: a warning dialog overlayed on a grayed out background of the app.

segment.source: the dialog asks the user if they want to switch apps and has ‘yes’ and ‘no’ buttons in the bottom right.
segment.target: the dialog asks the user if they want to switch apps and has ‘yes’ and ‘no’ buttons in the bottom right.

segment.source: the ‘no’ button is highlighted.
segment.target: the ‘no’ button is highlighted.

segment.source: If you always want this prompt to occur, use the Windows.System.LauncherOptions.TreatAsUntrusted property to indicate that the operating system display a warning.
segment.target: If you always want this prompt to occur, use the Windows.System.LauncherOptions.TreatAsUntrusted property to indicate that the operating system display a warning.

segment.source: Recommend an app
segment.target: Recommend an app

segment.source: In some cases, the user might not have an app installed to handle the URI that you are launching.
segment.target: In some cases, the user might not have an app installed to handle the URI that you are launching.

segment.source: By default, the operating system handles these cases by providing the user with a link to search for an appropriate app on the store.
segment.target: By default, the operating system handles these cases by providing the user with a link to search for an appropriate app on the store.

segment.source: If you want to give the user a specific recommendation for which app to acquire in this scenario, you can do so by passing that recommendation along with the URI that you are launching.
segment.target: If you want to give the user a specific recommendation for which app to acquire in this scenario, you can do so by passing that recommendation along with the URI that you are launching.

segment.source: Recommendations are also useful when more than one app has registered to handle a URI scheme.
segment.target: Recommendations are also useful when more than one app has registered to handle a URI scheme.

segment.source: By recommending a specific app, Windows will open that app if it is already installed.
segment.target: By recommending a specific app, Windows will open that app if it is already installed.

segment.source: To make a recommendation, call the Windows.System.Launcher.LaunchUriAsync(Uri, LauncherOptions) method with LauncherOptions.preferredApplicationPackageFamilyName set to the package family name of the app in the store that you want to recommend.
segment.target: To make a recommendation, call the Windows.System.Launcher.LaunchUriAsync(Uri, LauncherOptions) method with LauncherOptions.preferredApplicationPackageFamilyName set to the package family name of the app in the store that you want to recommend.

segment.source: The operating system uses this info to replace the general option to search for an app in the store with a specific option to acquire the recommended app from the store.
segment.target: The operating system uses this info to replace the general option to search for an app in the store with a specific option to acquire the recommended app from the store.

segment.source: Set remaining view preference
segment.target: Set remaining view preference

segment.source: Source apps that call LaunchUriAsync can request that they remain on screen after a URI launch.
segment.target: Source apps that call LaunchUriAsync can request that they remain on screen after a URI launch.

segment.source: By default, Windows attempts to share all available space equally between the source app and the target app that handles the URI.
segment.target: By default, Windows attempts to share all available space equally between the source app and the target app that handles the URI.

segment.source: Source apps can use the DesiredRemainingView property to indicate to the operating system that they prefer their app window to take up more or less of the available space.
segment.target: Source apps can use the DesiredRemainingView property to indicate to the operating system that they prefer their app window to take up more or less of the available space.

segment.source: DesiredRemainingView can also be used to indicate that the source app doesn't need to remain on screen after the URI launch and can be completely replaced by the target app.
segment.target: DesiredRemainingView can also be used to indicate that the source app doesn't need to remain on screen after the URI launch and can be completely replaced by the target app.

segment.source: This property only specifies the preferred window size of the calling app.
segment.target: This property only specifies the preferred window size of the calling app.

segment.source: It doesn't specify the behavior of other apps that may happen to also be on screen at the same time.
segment.target: It doesn't specify the behavior of other apps that may happen to also be on screen at the same time.

segment.source: Note Windows takes into account multiple different factors when it determines the source app's final window size, for example, the preference of the source app, the number of apps on screen, the screen orientation, and so on.
segment.target: Note Windows takes into account multiple different factors when it determines the source app's final window size, for example, the preference of the source app, the number of apps on screen, the screen orientation, and so on.

segment.source: By setting DesiredRemainingView, you aren't guaranteed a specific windowing behavior for the source app.
segment.target: By setting DesiredRemainingView, you aren't guaranteed a specific windowing behavior for the source app.

segment.source: Windows Maps app URI schemes
segment.target: Windows Maps app URI schemes

segment.source: Your app can use the bingmaps:, ms-drive-to:, and ms-walk-to: URI schemes to launch the Windows Maps app to specific maps, directions, and search results.
segment.target: Your app can use the bingmaps:, ms-drive-to:, and ms-walk-to: URI schemes to launch the Windows Maps app to specific maps, directions, and search results.

segment.source: For example, the following URI opens the Windows Maps app and displays a map centered over New York City.
segment.target: For example, the following URI opens the Windows Maps app and displays a map centered over New York City.

segment.source: an example of the windows maps app.
segment.target: an example of the windows maps app.

segment.source: For more info, see Launch the Windows Maps app.
segment.target: For more info, see Launch the Windows Maps app.

segment.source: To use the map control in your own app, see Display maps with 2D, 3D, and Streetside views.
segment.target: To use the map control in your own app, see Display maps with 2D, 3D, and Streetside views.

segment.source: Windows Settings app URI scheme
segment.target: Windows Settings app URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the ms-settings: URI scheme to launch the Windows Settings app.
segment.target: Your app can use the ms-settings: URI scheme to launch the Windows Settings app.

segment.source: Launching to the Settings app is an important part of writing a privacy-aware app.
segment.target: Launching to the Settings app is an important part of writing a privacy-aware app.

segment.source: If your app can't access a sensitive resource, we recommend providing the user a convenient link to the privacy settings for that resource.
segment.target: If your app can't access a sensitive resource, we recommend providing the user a convenient link to the privacy settings for that resource.

segment.source: For example, the following URI opens the Settings app and displays the camera privacy settings.
segment.target: For example, the following URI opens the Settings app and displays the camera privacy settings.

segment.source: camera privacy settings.
segment.target: camera privacy settings.

segment.source: For more info, see Launch the Windows Settings app and Guidelines for privacy-aware apps.
segment.target: For more info, see Launch the Windows Settings app and Guidelines for privacy-aware apps.

segment.source: Windows Store app URI scheme
segment.target: Windows Store app URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the ms-windows-store: URI scheme to Launch the Windows Store app.
segment.target: Your app can use the ms-windows-store: URI scheme to Launch the Windows Store app.

segment.source: Open product detail pages, product review pages, and search pages, etc. For example, the following URI opens the Windows Store app and launches the home page of the Store.
segment.target: Open product detail pages, product review pages, and search pages, etc. For example, the following URI opens the Windows Store app and launches the home page of the Store.

segment.source: For more info, see Launch the Windows Store app.
segment.target: For more info, see Launch the Windows Store app.

segment.source: Call app URI scheme
segment.target: Call app URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the ms-call: URI scheme to launch the Call app.
segment.target: Your app can use the ms-call: URI scheme to launch the Call app.

segment.source: URI Scheme
segment.target: URI Scheme

segment.source: Results
segment.target: Results

segment.source: ms-call:settings
segment.target: ms-call:settings

segment.source: Launches the Calls app settings page.
segment.target: Launches the Calls app settings page.

segment.source: Chat app URI scheme
segment.target: Chat app URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the ms-chat: URI scheme to launch the Messaging app.
segment.target: Your app can use the ms-chat: URI scheme to launch the Messaging app.

segment.source: URI scheme
segment.target: URI scheme

segment.source: Results
segment.target: Results

segment.source: ms-chat:
segment.target: ms-chat:

segment.source: Launches the Messaging app.
segment.target: Launches the Messaging app.

segment.source: ms-chat:?ContactID={contacted}
segment.target: ms-chat:?ContactID={contacted}

segment.source: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a particular contact’s information.
segment.target: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a particular contact’s information.

segment.source: ms-chat:?Body={body}
segment.target: ms-chat:?Body={body}

segment.source: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a string to use as the content of the message.
segment.target: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a string to use as the content of the message.

segment.source: ms-chat:?Addresses={address}&Body={body}
segment.target: ms-chat:?Addresses={address}&Body={body}

segment.source: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a particular addresses' information, and with a string to use as the content of the message.
segment.target: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a particular addresses' information, and with a string to use as the content of the message.

segment.source: Note: Addresses can be concatenated.
segment.target: Note: Addresses can be concatenated.

segment.source: ms-chat:?TransportId={transportId}
segment.target: ms-chat:?TransportId={transportId}

segment.source: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a particular transport ID.
segment.target: Allows the messaging application to be launched with a particular transport ID.

segment.source: Email URI scheme
segment.target: Email URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the mailto: URI scheme to launch the default mail app.
segment.target: Your app can use the mailto: URI scheme to launch the default mail app.

segment.source: URI Scheme
segment.target: URI Scheme

segment.source: Results
segment.target: Results

segment.source: mailto:
segment.target: mailto:

segment.source: Launches the default email app.
segment.target: Launches the default email app.

segment.source: mailto:\[email address\]
segment.target: mailto:\[email address\]

segment.source: Launches the email app and creates a new message with the specified email address on the To line.
segment.target: Launches the email app and creates a new message with the specified email address on the To line.

segment.source: Note that the email is not sent until the user taps send.
segment.target: Note that the email is not sent until the user taps send.

segment.source: HTTP URI scheme
segment.target: HTTP URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the http: URI scheme to launch the default web browser.
segment.target: Your app can use the http: URI scheme to launch the default web browser.

segment.source: URI Scheme
segment.target: URI Scheme

segment.source: Results
segment.target: Results

segment.source: http:
segment.target: http:

segment.source: Launches the default web browser.
segment.target: Launches the default web browser.

segment.source: Nearby Numbers app URI scheme
segment.target: Nearby Numbers app URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the ms-yellowpage: URI scheme to launch the Nearby Numbers app.
segment.target: Your app can use the ms-yellowpage: URI scheme to launch the Nearby Numbers app.

segment.source: URI Scheme
segment.target: URI Scheme

segment.source: Results
segment.target: Results

segment.source: ms-yellowpage:?input=\[keyword\]&method=\[String
segment.target: ms-yellowpage:?input=\[keyword\]&method=\[String

segment.source: Launches the installed Point of Interest (POI) search app that supports this new URI.
segment.target: Launches the installed Point of Interest (POI) search app that supports this new URI.

segment.source: People app URI scheme
segment.target: People app URI scheme

segment.source: Your app can use the ms-people: URI scheme to launch the People app.
segment.target: Your app can use the ms-people: URI scheme to launch the People app.

segment.source: For more info, see Launch the People app.
segment.target: For more info, see Launch the People app.
